etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in Widsith. From long + beard

definitions: Frequently with capital initial. Used to denote a person. Medieval History. A Lombard.

notes.text: In post-medieval use, frequently as an etymologizing calque of Lombard, Langobard, etc.

definitions: A man with a long beard. Frequently with the implication of old age, wisdom, eccentricity, or distinguished character.
The mature adult male of a wild turkey, typically one over two years old, which has a long beard-like tuft of feathers below the base of its neck.
